questions.text: An investigator is studying cell signaling in the enteric nervous system. In order to stimulate gut peristalsis, acetylcholine binds and activates its G-protein coupled receptor. Which of the following is expected to result from this interaction?
questions.solution:
The Gq receptor is one of the three types of G-protein-coupled receptors. G-protein-coupled receptors are seven-pass transmembrane receptors that have an alpha, beta, and gamma subunit. When a ligand binds, this activates the G-protein by allowing GTP to bind to the alpha subunit instead of GDP. This allows the alpha subunit to dissociate from the rest of the G-protein and either activate or inhibit other proteins in the cell (depending on which type of G-protein it is).  

Gq is one type of G protein, that once activated, it activates an enzyme called PLC which then cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate into inositol triphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). Both IP3 and DAG work together to continue the signaling. IP3 stimulates calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The released calcium helps DAG activate a protein called protein kinase C, which then starts acting on other proteins and activating them, thereby inducing the response of the cells.  

Other examples of hormones that have Gq-coupled receptors are gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), Oxytocin, Antidiuretic hormone (V1-receptor), Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), Histamine (H1-receptor), Angiotensin II, and gastrin.  


Option Analysis

❌ Formation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate  :
Incorrect: Ligand binding to a Gs receptor leads to activation of adenylate cyclase and formation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). An example of Gs receptors are beta-1 receptors that lead to increased heart rate and contractility. However, the acetylcholine receptor is coupled with Gq not Gs.   
❌ Cross-phosphorylation of tyrosine residues  :
Incorrect: Cross-phosphorylation of tyrosine residues occurs in receptor tyrosine kinases. An example of a tyrosine kinase receptor is the insulin receptor.   
✅ Formation of inositol triphosphate  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Activation of protein kinase A  :
 Incorrect: Ligand binding to a Gs receptor leads to activation of adenylate cyclase and formation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). Then, cAMP activates protein kinase A by releasing it from its regulatory subunit. An example of Gs receptors are beta-1 receptors that lead to increased heart rate and contractility.  
❌ Inhibition of adenylate cyclase  :
 Incorrect: Ligand binding to a Gi receptor leads to inactivation of adenylate cyclase. This is useful for negative feedback on Gs and inactivation of cells. An example of Gi receptors are M2 receptors that lead to decreased heart rate and atrial contractility.

questions.text: An investigator is studying virulence factors that assist bacteria to evade host immune responses. Human white blood cells and group A streptococci are inoculated together, with observed uptake of group A streptococci into the cytoplasm of macrophages. Which of the following structures are unique to this endocytosis pathway?
questions.solution:
The three main methods of endocytosis are phagocytosis, pinocytosis, and receptor-mediated endocytosis. In phagocytosis, debris, bacteria, and dead cells are engulfed by specific phagocytic cells to form phagosomes. These cells then fuse with lysosomes to form phagolysosomes, which degrade engulfed bacterial or foreign material.  

Pinocytosis is used by most cells for the uptake of extracellular fluid and dissolved molecules. This process involves the invagination of cell membranes with vesicle formation and transport to the cytosol via motor proteins. Receptor-mediated endocytosis for uptake of specific molecules (e.g., iron and cholesterol). In this process, clathrin-coated pits lined with receptors bind to a specific molecule. The edges of the pit coalesce with the subsequent linkage of clathrin proteins. Subsequently, the vesicle pinches off and merges with the endosome to separate receptors into a second vesicle. The clathrin detaches and returns to the cell membrane.



Option Analysis

❌ Lysosomes:
Incorrect: Lysosomes are organelles that degrade waste and cellular debris, both from inside and outside the cell. Lysosomes are not unique to the phagocytosis pathway.
✅ Phagosomes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endosomes:
Incorrect: Endosomes are organelles that are important in receptor-mediated endocytosis. Vesicles that contain receptors bound to their specific target (e.g., transferrin, LDL) fuse with endosomes, which function to separate the receptor from its target. They are not involved in phagocytosis.  
❌ Clathrin-coated pits:
Incorrect: Clathrin-coated pits are unique to receptor-mediated endocytosis. Clathrin coats the intracellular side of pits that contain receptors. After specific molecules (e.g., transferrin, LDL) have bound these receptors, the clathrin molecules link together to form a vesicle. The clathrin then dissociates from the vesicle and returns to the cell surface. They are not involved in phagocytosis.
❌ Kinesin and dynein  :
Incorrect: Kinesin and dynein are molecular motor proteins that transport cellular material along the microtubules towards their target destination. These motor proteins are not unique to the phagocytosis pathway.

questions.text: A study is conducted to evaluate the various effects of receptors on cardiac cells. According to this study,  if receptor X in the atria was activated, it led to inhibition of secondary messengers production including cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), leading to decreased heart rate and contractility. Which of the following receptors is receptor X?
questions.solution:
G protein-coupled receptors are seven-pass transmembrane receptors. The intracellular part of the receptor contains a G protein which has three subunits; alpha, beta, and gamma. When the receptor is inactivated, the alpha subunit binds to GDP and is connected to beta and gamma. Once the ligand binds to the receptor, the alpha binds to GTP and is dissociated from the beta and gamma subunits and it results in an intracellular (either activation or inhibitory depending on the type of the G protein).  

Gi (G inhibitory) is a class of G protein that acts in an opposite fashion to Gs. Once Gi is activated it inhibits the enzyme adenylate cyclase, leading to inhibition of the production of secondary intracellular messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). Gi mainly works as a regulatory and as part of a feedback mechanism. Some examples of G-protein coupled receptors with Gi-protein class include M2 cholinergic receptor in the atria, alpha-2 adrenergic receptor, and D2 (dopamine) receptors.  


Option Analysis

✅ M2 cholinergic receptor  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Beta-1 adrenergic receptor  :
Incorrect: When Beta-1 adrenergic receptors are activated this leads to stimulation of secondary messenger production (cAMP) and eventually increased heart rate and contractility.   
❌ M1 cholinergic receptor  :
Incorrect: The M1 cholinergic receptor is also a G-protein-coupled receptor; however, it is not found in the heart but in the central nervous system. Also, the class of G-protein in the M1 receptor is Gq protein, not Gi.  
❌ H2 (histamine) receptor  :
Incorrect: The class of G protein in the H2 receptor is Gs, not Gi. This type of receptor is not found in cardiac tissue.   
❌ M3 cholinergic receptor  :
Incorrect: M3 cholinergic receptor is a G-protein-coupled receptor, found in a variety of tissues but not the heart. The class of G-proteins in the M3 receptor is Gq, not Gi.

questions.text: A study is conducted to evaluate the responses of the cells to various hormones. Hormone X is evaluated and is found that it stimulates a transmembrane receptor resulting in activation of protein kinase A following a robust increase in the concentration of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). Hormone X is likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
G protein-coupled receptors are seven-pass transmembrane receptors. The intracellular part of the receptor contains a G protein which has three subunits; alpha, beta, and gamma. When the receptor is inactivated, the alpha subunit binds to GDP and is connected to beta and gamma. Once the ligand binds to the receptor, the alpha binds to GTP and is dissociated from the beta and gamma subunits and it results in an intracellular (either activation or inhibitory depending on the type of the G protein).

Gs is one type of G protein; once it is activated, the alpha subunit of Gs activates an enzyme called Adenylate cyclase (AC). AC cleaves ATP and produces cAMP. cAMP then binds and activates a protein called protein kinase A. Finally, after it is activated protein Kinase A starts phosphorylating and activating other proteins and thereby inducing the response of the cell.  

Examples of hormones that have Gs-coupled receptors include follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH),  luteinizing hormone (LH), Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH),  Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), antidiuretic hormone (V2- receptor), Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), parathyroid hormone, Calcitonin, Histamine (H2-receptor), Glucagon, Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).  


Option Analysis

✅ Glucagon:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)  :
Incorrect: TRH receptors are also G protein-coupled receptors; however, the type of G protein is Gq, which results in the production of inositol triphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) from the cleavage of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate. This eventually activates protein kinase C, not A.   
❌ Thyroid hormones   :
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone receptors are intracellular not transmembrane receptors.  
❌ Cortisol:
Incorrect: Cortisol receptors are also intracellular receptors.  
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: Insulin receptors are tyrosine kinase receptors that once activated phosphorylates its own tyrosine residues.
